ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course is amazing. I left the course with crucial photoshop and photography skills.
I learned how to properly use a camera, how to edit photos, and how to print photos.
I learned how to look at photography, use a camera, photoshop, and take better photos.
Taking photos with DSLR, editing workflow with Bridge and Photoshop, looking at other photographers' works
Photoshop, how to use a Camera, and how to convey a message using the camera.
Thinking critically about what is and what isn't included in my composition.
I learned the basics of operating a digital camera and editing photos in Camera Raw and Photoshop. I also saw some cool examples of digital photography from my TA and from the Yale archives.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The biggest weakness is that there are so many costs included in taking this class -- renting/buying a camera, printing paper, portfolio binder, etc.
I appreciated the flexibility of the course, but I do wish there was a bit more structure.

The professor and TA were awesome! The strength of the course was that it was very creative and flexible, unlike most other courses at Yale. You could take photos of whatever interested you and the professor and TA would help you with it. I also really appreciated the critiques.

Strengths: Tremendously fun course, Ted is great and Hobbes is an amazing TA. Class feels relaxed and you can really dive into any type of subject matter. Weaknesses: the beginning half of the class is kind of slow (so meeting twice a week for 2 hours each feels tedious), but the second half of class when printing for final crits feel rushed

Strengths: lots of freedom in deciding what to take photos of, 1-on-1 support in class from the professor and TA whenever we asked for help, cool studio visits in the art school

Weaknesses: I wish that there had been clearer feedback during the critsobviously art is subjective, but I liked whenever the professor told us when he thought a photo was strong or when he thought it needed improvement and why. As someone relatively new to photography I would have appreciated more guidance.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I think this course is great for anyone who wants to try their hand at photography.
Yes! Whether you are a photography beginner or more advanced, you will learn more!
Yes definitely! Ted is a lovely person who is very invested in his students.
I would recommend this course! It was a low-stress way to explore photography.

I would recommend this course to someone who wants to learn the basics of photography or to a photographer who wants a space for independent practice. It was really enjoyable to be assigned 100 photos every week of whatever we wanted, and to practice photography on an everyday basis.
